Cheap isekai anime has ravaged the industry for a number of years now. Without a working vaccine, the disease continues to kill the brain cells of viewers everywhere. The Sasuga Skeletor Sama Series is just another symptom of this plague. 
The story has been done thousands of times. It's the generic MC self insert type of story. I can literally predict the outcome of every episode after about two minutes since nothing will ever stump Skeletor Sama. He will always achieve victory no matter what. He would conquer the world in 7 days but apparently the author thinks resisting the urge of dicking around inhis harem should be the main obstacle Skeletor Sama needs to overcome throughout the series. After three seasons I still have no idea where this show is going. Then the realization dawned on me. The point of the show is not to actually tell a good story, but for the author to mentally masturbate onto a piece of paper so the target audience will lap up the discharge like a bunch of coco addicts trying to snort a bag of baking soda. 


Skeletor Sama is the character equivalent of play-doh. He will change and do whatever seems the edgiest and coolest in the moment. Side characters are irrelevant since the series is focusing on Skeletor Sama himself. They will either circlejerk how they want to bone him or get killed and have only one or two episodes of screen time. 


One thing I think studio Madhouse did brilliantly is saving a ton of money not animating Skeletor Sama. If not for the sound and subtitles changing on the bottom of the screen I would have thought that my internet went out whenever Skeletor Sama is on screen. I was wondering why this show looks Master of Ragnarok tier despite it being popular and lucrative enough to have three seasons until I realized that both shows takes place in Yggdrasil where things look cheap and lacking in pixels.


I totally get it. We all occasionally want to just turn off our brain and watch a show like this when we are bored. Sometimes we do have no other choice but to pull over at that really dirty KFC on the side of the road at 3 in the morning. But why would I do that when Popeyes and Church's are just next door, are cheaper, and doesn't taste like diarrhea? There are 40-50 shows airing every single season and are you seriously telling me that you cannot find a single other show on that list that will be a better time spent than watching this?


In conclusion I would just like to say thank mr skeltal for the good bones and calcium to heal my head after slamming it on my desk thinking about the possibility of this getting a fourth season.

This is a very troubled, very flawed anime with many many many problems. It is also extremely frustrating to watch. 
*sighs*
The main issue is that it is In DIRE need of a better director. The pacing is shot, and too many times the anime starts building up for something important, then the important scene suddenly happens offscreen, is botched in some crazy way, or fail to deliver. Every time you think... but it'll get better! Just soon! Just around the corner! The one awesome episode is nearly there! And then it ends, and you realize that you watched 13 episodes of teasing and cliffhangers thatresulted in nothing.


Another issue is that it utilizes really badly done CG visuals. There are titles that know how to use CG well (for example, Sidonia no Kishi, Ajin 1st season, Seikai Suru Kado)... but this is not one of them. CG monsters look like cel-shaded video game characters, and are not impressive. And there are a lot of CG monsters. I also suspect that they blew half their animation budget on certain creature, judging how horrible certain soldiers looked in comparison. 


The most irritating thing is that through all that mess you see glimpses of genius now and then, but the glimpses never blossom into anything bigger. 


I suppose at this point I should jsut read the damn sourrce material in japanese. It looks like the writer was onto something, it is just anime isn't good in comparison.


Detailed breakdown below:


Story: 3/10

Good things about it is that we have villain protagonists, malevolent protagonist, monster protagonists... this is a breath of fresh air. Sometimes it results in pointlessly brutal sequences that don't see to have any real reason to be there, and characters being intorduced only to be killed off by protagonsits (in a horrible way), but.... it is possible to live with that.


The bad part of the whole thing is horrible slow pacing, and too much teasing, playing bait and switch and displaying important events offscreen. Remember how in 2nd season certain grand battle with sebastian happened offscreen? Same happens here too. Basically, the anime tries to build up, then slow things down, stretch story arc out, and when you think it is about to deliver something amazing, it fails to deliver.


Compared to 1st and 2nd season there is significantly small number of "awesome!!" moments, to the point where I'm not sure if it was worth watching at all.


As I said, it badly needs better director. There's something good in the source material, just the anime should've been better.


Art: 4/10

A lot more CG in this season, and CG is quite bad. I mean, it wasn't great in 2nd season either, but there wasn't a whole lot of it, but now it is in every frame to the point of being eyesore.


CG Animation is bad, with awkward movement, and  certain models look extremely cheap. They definitely haven't gotten hang of this tech in this season. 


Certain special effects look like they were lifted straight from the nineties, to be honest. They definitely should take a look at Ajin (1st season), Sidonia no Kishi, and nother CG anime. To see how the technology can be used in better way. Hell, just Guilty Gear Xrd Sign would teach them a lot.


Sound 5/10: Nothing outstanding, although on occasion some themes are real nice. The anime doesn't let those tunes play for long, though.


Characters: 5/10:

I spent most of the time being irritated by poor directing, so I don't remember much about them. Which means they're not very memorable.


Enjoyment: 3/10:

Constant bait and switch with teasing cliffhangers, promises of amazing events around the corner, which fail to materialize. All. The. Time. This results in extreme irritation.


Overall: 3/10;


I didn't like it at all. The anime did spark my interest in source material, but it is too poorly done to recommend it. Might be worth a watch if you're bored out of your mind or something.

First of all, I have to mention that the original story is great. This anime adaptation however is an abomination and clear cash grab trying to profit from a dedicated fan base. I'm going to keep this review short because I can not be bothered.
Just search "Overlord goblin army cgi" on YouTube and you can deduce my opinion. The show is filled with stuff like this. For a bit more of a rant and a more grounded opinion, read below:
Story: This adaptation suffers from major pacing issues. While the original story is great, the anime can not do it justice. While we are shown thedark side of Ains' campaign to conquer the world, we also have to sit through several episodes of failed character building for the people of Carne Village. It's slow, it's boring but there was potential for these characters. Madhouse just squandered that potential.


Art: What art? The story is plagued with bad CGI, to the point that is seems to want to compete with Berserk for worst CGI of the last decade. It might even win that competition as even Berserk knew that some stylisation was required, but here an army consisting of a single copy-pasted soldiers just bounces of a shield wall, like cartoon characters. The thing is, this is no cartoon. Like I said previously, just search  "Overlord goblin army cgi" on YouTube


Characters: awful story pacing and truly bad CGI squanders the potential of the characters.


Sound: not bad, not great. As usual, both the OP and ED are good, though seasons 1 and 2 were better.


Enjoyment  and overall score: I could not enjoy this show due to the disrespect of studio Madhouse in regards to this show and its fanbase. The only reason I watched this show to completion is because the underlying potential is great. But I now regret waiting for it and not reading the LN instead

To put it bluntly: If you liked the previous 2 seasons, you'll enjoy this. 
However, you must understand that this anime does have quite a bit of world building and its necessary to further enhance the story so bare with it.
Another thing to note is that this anime isnt you typical Isekai anime. The main story  n all seasons are about ainz and his comrades who are NOT hero's. This is an Antihero show at heart. so if your ok with that then you'll be fine, otherwise you will be disgusted and angry at some parts so beware.
art is fantastic, madhouse did a greatjob blending typical animation with CG.


sounds is also fantastic, sound effects and voices are great.


characters are diverse and well introduced.


the story is good however with the pacing the show takes and the fact that it is only a 13ep season, it can feel rushed. IMO this should of been 26ep per season show from the beginning as the show Leaves ALOT out from the LN's.

This season was pretty hard to stand out in with shows like Attack on Titan or Steins;Gate making comebacks. However, for me, it managed to make an impression enough for me to begin buying the LN's.
Starting off, the biggest issue of the season is the poor CGI. That's all I really want to say about it, because it's had this for three seasons. If you are still complaining about how you'll drop the show due to it after watching almost 40 episodes of it, then you really don't have much conviction. This is why I'm also not putting art at an 8 or 9, asI believe most of the character designs are distinct and interesting otherwise. Granted, they come from a light novel with established designs. The biggest problem with this CGI is it can take you out of otherwise enthralling scenes.


Moving past that, the series really shines with two things: Ainz interacting with his subordinates, and Ainz interacting with lesser life forms (read humans). The more Ainz interacts with the NPC's, the more you understand what drives him and what originally drove the guild he and his friends made. What you're supposed to understand is that conversations with these NPC's are, by extension, conversations with his old friends. This is part of the reason I've put character so high. While interacting with humans however, you'll see him full of disdain unless they go to great heights to prove themselves to him. Some theorize this is just because he didn't like humans back in the real world, however the show plays it off as his stats as a Lich making him unable to feel empathy for them. Overall, some interesting conversations and dynamics are shown whenever Ainz talks to someone or explains his plans (Sasuga, Ainz sama).


Sound was phenomenal, almost exclusively for one of the sickest OP's I've seen in a couple years. Easily that has to be in my top 5. But the sounds for battles, fights, and for most voice actors all came off the way they are intended. There's not much else to point out regarding this.


Finally, the story progression is slow but usually pays off in 2 or 3 arcs coming to a conclusion. I won't really go into spoilers, but Carne Village is a major focus this season, as well as the kingdom of E-Rantel as a whole. Finally, we're seeing Ainz interact with and act out towards the surrounding kingdoms, which has really taken the last two seasons to build up to.


At the end of it all, I think Overlord III brought a great show to bat. It really was the highlight of my summer season past Steins;Gate and and ecchi I watched. If you've seen the other two seasons it's really worth your time, and here's hoping for a season 4.

With this season of Overlord you truly got to experience how much of a badass Ainz truly is.  I think this definitely is the best season overall.
Story:  With anyone who knows anything about Overlord, you know that the story doesn't mainly focus around Ainz but other characters as well.  But I just want to talk about Ainz.  Basically this season, he finds out that he wants world domination and focuses on how he can accomplish this.  But he also has to worry about intruders, keeping a village safe and who he should alliance with.  This season I think hasmore Ainz than any other season!


Art:  Art for this anime is always good.  CGI though could have been a little better but I'm not too much of a stickler on that shit. 


Sound:  The opening theme and ending theme to this anime is always so catchy.  Especially this season.  I never had to skip like i usually do with most shows I'm watching.  All the voices of the characters sounded good as well.


Character:  Like i said before, Ainz is a badass.  You really get to see how powerful he is and how actually evil he is to his enemies.  The floor guardians were fun to watch as always as well. If anything I wish there was more yandere Albedo moments.


Enjoyment, Overall:  Overall i really enjoyed this season.  It felt like it went by so fast.  I wish they would make more episodes for a season but that just shows how much I like this anime.  Cant wait for season 4 if it does come!!

Skip to 5th paragraph for just story, art, sound, and character ratings
With the 3rd season finally coming to a close, I can now say that this anime wasn't good and will probably never going to be good. From recommendations to giant banners at public events, I was expecting at least a good show, but I was wrong, this was just a waste of time.
Before I talk about things that bothered me, I will name a couple things that I found enjoyable (only partially in some cases). First of all, the world is seems dense with a lot of classic mmorpg elements that I enjoy, theauthor either played mmorpgs before or did a lot of research on them. Second, ops and eds were lowkey bangers. And last, I do enjoy self-inserting myself into Ainz when I have a bad day, though this doesn't mean the show is good, Ainz being a blatant self-insert is no different than any other similar isekai shows.


This show is very similar to another show this season called The Master of Ragnarok & Blesser of Einherjar, comparing to that downright unbearable feces which I immediately dropped after about 4 minutes, overlord did a good job into tricking the viewers into thinking that the show isn't the same as ragnarok by having a "darker tone" and a harem that's bigger than all of the harem protags combined. Awfully similar to that one dude's show that has the entire cast of females playing around with his swords huh.


-Story: 3, no coherent story from my viewing, it might be because I wasn't paying attention because the show bored me to death, but all I gathered from the story is that this dude gets transported to a video game and he's op af and he has a giant harem of slaves so he goes around and fuck with ants so that the other dudes that might've got transported as well will notice their kouhai. 


-Art: 2, this ain't it chief, this ain't how an edgy 12 yr old that's a little horny self-insert show supposed to look like, the show looks ugly as hell, with a gripping narrative it wouldn't have been a big deal, but this doesn't have that, the cgi are berserk level terrible, there's barely any animation, the characters just look like they have half the amount of pixels Asuna has, and the backgrounds look like a pre-rendered PUBG map.


-Sound: 3, nothing stand out from the ost, the sound designs are terrible, episode 12 had like a league of legends queue popping noise. Nothing too special about voice acting, Ainz just has one tone, and the girls sound cute I guess.  


-Character 3, Ainz has barely personality other than yea i miss my gamers and offu this girl kinda cute yo she on me what i gonna do, sometimes he just does things that're similar to pouring salt on snails. Nothing interesting about the pseudo-spurned women's (and men's) club either. One side character has more character traits than the entire cast and even they have barely any. 


My enjoyment is my overall, 3, insert your butt into Ainz for a quick delusion rush and that's it.

My small mid-season review. The season is hearting up, Ainz is planning ahead and trying has best to portray himself as supreme leader. The season so far has been very enjoyable and as someone who has not read the manga it's been easier to follow than season 2. 
As always the case with overlord, each episode is well paced making them feel like that are only 5 minutes long rather than 20 (yes i'm enjoying them that much). The art style is the same as always, with 3D animated 'stuff' thrown in, which I really wish they didn't do. But the character development, story andsound track all make up for that. 


One reason why I've always like overlord is that is very unique in the isekai genre, it doesn't feel like ideas are recycled and the goal of the main character is mediocre (Find a way to get home). This has stayed truth throughout the seasons and this one is no exception. 


Overall I looking forward to the rest of the season and wishing that it was 24 episodes rather than 13.

first and foremost, I apologize for some grammar error. I hope you still get what I wanted to say,
Overlord continues to surprise me. When I first watched it, I had a really low expectation in this next Isekai. No, this show is definitely not a masterpiece. But it did really well to grab my attention in the first season. Now, in the first and second season, this show is kinda mediocre to me. But it was a hell of fun for me to have watched it. Because if you look for it, this show has little going for it: Animation-wise this show is good butnot outstanding, It's not full of action, the overpowered main character, yadda yadda yadda. If I had to choose for animation between overlord and SAO I'd definitely have chosen SAO. BUT WAIT, this anime is one of the example why anime still needs to adapt light novel:


The story. The one that surprises me in overlord is that they have that balance between you pity the side character and the point of Ainz Ooal Gown's character. Now what do I mean by that? For example, if they kill certain character that has good deeds and make the character gone forever from the story, a lot of people will get upset, because so much is wasted from the character development. BUT, if you don't kill the character that has encountered Ainz Ooal Gown just because they have good deeds, that would kill the point of Ainz Ooal Gown's character, because if they do that, that would be the next Kirito Art Online, the next "Good Guy", I wouldn't want to watch that kind of show, especially if the animation is definitely inferior to the Sword Art Online. So they master that balance of character and story and have keep that until now the third season. That is impressive. Yes there is a lot of trash light novel out there that get adapted to anime, but this show is not one of that. 


Definitely enjoyable to watch!

Overlord season II wasn't as good as season I and it fell flat to me, i thought that the creators had no idea what to do with the characters. Season 3 was a interesting one  i like the theme of the whole light novel and anime, even if its a MMORPG type anime still it captures reality in a way that most TV shows books, anime dare not go. I'm talking about the concept of Good and Evil which is a made up fantasy concept, and in reality people only are interested in their own personal gain, and self interest if it doesn't suitthem they change their tactics and alliances. My point is I like that there isn't a real concept of good and evil to drive the plot, and the characters are driven by pure interest.

That's incredible and original anime. Significantly different from others in the same genre.
Firstly, there is no harem as such, although at first glance it may seem that there is one.
Secondly,Unlike the ordinary anime, The main character is imperturbable, self confident, calm and he makes quite rational decisions, there are no emotions inside him. Main hero is rather cruel, what is extremely unusual for protagonist heroes in anime. But even in spite of this, The Main hero have some humanity and steadfastness.
 Thirdly, in this anime there is an impressive logical and fascinating plot, that does not force you to give up watching, as there are noepisodes that would not affect the main development of events. (Although half the episodes of the 2nd season were not very interesting)


Fourthly, the nature and the abundance of characters, the creation of conditions are helping complete immersion into the world of this anime. Such things as : the map of the world, the state, the hierarchy of society, the relationship of states and social classes, the hierarchy of magic, relationships and other things greatly done.


Fifth, the absence of a huge amount of garbage fan-service (I think there's no need to explain)


Sixth, again I repeat about the plot: it has a very unexpected outcome.


Well, in general, the list of merits can be continued, but those that I have already described have particularly hooked me.


We turn to the disadvantages:

1. The presence of the series, which take a large amount of time, but do not have a significant impact on the main plot (especially important in the second season). 2. There are some not very interesting series, that are quite boring to watch (but there are few of them).

3. The intentional protractedness of some moments in the series.

 4. Presence of predictability of some events.


Well that's all. I hope my review will help you. I really recommend watching this anime, as well as for an avid otaku (who has not watched it), as well as for new anime artists, quite INCREDIBLE and ORIGINAL anime.

So many tens? But it contained so many "fillers"! 
Well allow me to explain to you why I felt the urge to write a review for this as well as my reasoning behind the given score. 
A lot people watching this or people that have completed season 3 will share a similar thought "so many fillers!", but first what actually is a filler? A filler is an episode that can be considered a spin-off where the episode/arc has literally no connection or impact on the actual story/plot. For example an episode dedicated to a beach event for a fan service, where the characters after theepisode have no memories about the events that occurred nor will they ever mention it. The MC not having (much) screen time doesn't mean that the story is on halt. The story develops and the others getting screen time is extremely important for the climax. 


This season has not a single filler episode, neither did the previous seasons. We have to realize that Ainz his main objective is to figure out if other human beings like him were trapped in the slightly modified version of Yggdrasil. In order to achieve this goal he has established a small building and plans to make his name known throughout the world so that other players might be able to encounter him or to figure out that they aren't alone. And together they might figure out a solution to them being trapped in a game.


Recaps aside. If you haven't watched the previous seasons then this review might be confusing. If you are into anime that are about MC being trapped in a game and absolutely dominating the game with strategic moves while not flexing then you are in for an amazing ride. This show is fairly unique. I do recommend to watch it, season 1 has great reviews. This review focuses on the audience that is already familiar with Overlord.


This season continued where season 2 left off; establishing a small village/city not only to spread his name (which his followers inclined on), but also to do research for the greater good. 


Story:

In this season Ainz will even increase the size of his territory more, significantly more. After all his goal has become world domination. Having his name spread through good or evil doesn't matter, as long as it reaches other players and not npc's. That's why we have seen 2 faces from him, the Sorcerer King and Momon of the Darkness. One being the evil lord, showing no mercy to puny beings, obliberating them as he pleases. And the other being the kind adamantite warrior that tries to see the good in everything while helping fellow adventurers. 

Both of these are very important in spreading his name, one will be known as an evil person and the other as a good person. At the final episode it will also be shown why Momon's presence is of essence. Even though... we can't actually say that he had planned this from the start. Because after all we know that Demiurge is an extremely clever strategist and planner. 

This season shows the potential of Ainz his power as both the "hero" and the "evil" person. It also finally shows how powerful he actually is... well at least it shows what he can do with a single spell, let alone when he tried. And this is something that many fans wished to see animated. 

The story progresses further in how those around Ainz help him realize his goal and partly focusses on the small village that once was protected by Ainz. 


Art:

As usual the art is very pleasing. It really suits the given theme and setting. The environments are beautiful and the gore where needed is very pleasing. When something gets intense the art shows the details of the scene, making me a very happy person.


Sound:

The sound effects are superb. In combination with the art they really do know how to keep you excited throughout the whole episode, not to mention season. They even paid attention to small details such as ambient sounds and sfx of enemies when the camera was focused at a place where there was no combat, but hearing it in the background made it fairly realistic for that matter.


Character:

The character development is very neat. We learn more and see a lot more about the villagers and their capabilities as well as trust and love towards each other. All these developments aren't fillers because they are necessary for the story. Each and every single character serves an important role in the universe of Overlord. One is a genius when it comes to herbs and potions, the other in terms of magic is extremely advanced, while others are used to simply show how mighty and powerful Ainz is compared to those npc's. Plenty of them had interesting background stories making me love more characters in this show than I anticipated I would. 


Enjoyment:

I don't think I need to explain this with the previous points, but I absolutely loved it. Especially when Ainz made himself more known in terms of power. There were moments that I felt sad, but that adds up in the enjoyment factor, because sadness is an emotion, while not positive it was caused in a good way by a show. And that makes it more thrilling, because you can live with the characters and imagine how easy/hard things might just be for them. This makes the show immersive and that is something that not many shows nail. 


I do hope this review might've changed your opinion about season 3 of Overlord and perhaps might be just the reason to start with the series.

The third season of overlord is good and that's pushing it. (Please don't get triggered hear me out). Overlord does the overpowered protagonist right, which is very difficult to do. There are two ways to do overpowered protagonists right. First way is a one punch man approach where you use comedy. Overlord uses a different approach. Overlord mainly focuses on the support characters. Overlord uses support characters to world build and show power differences (while making the story interesting). Because lets face it if the story was just about Ains it would be extremely boring. The main problem I have with overlord in general isthe fact that in some events its impossible to know what the hell is going on or the deeper meaning behind events (this applies to all three seasons). Its also funny because Ains also doesn't even know what going on so I can relate haha. 


Story: To continue to elaborate on my problem of Overlord is there are a few episodes that feel pointless or I just never understood why they invested so much time into them. An example of this is in season two. In season two half of the season was spend on the lizard men. There was absolutely no reason to why they needed to spend so much time on characters that would only make a couple appearances in the future (so far). This season, the Giant of the east and demon snake of the west episode seemed like it was filler and pointless. Another "pointless episodes" were the tomb raider episodes. They invested a lot of time into these characters just to have them (spoiler alert please skip if you haven't watched I apologize) brutally slaughtered. The last couple episodes were rushed but still enjoyable. Highlights would be the Carne village episodes. All of the character there are amazing and seem real, it was nice seeing them this season. 


Art: Not much to say, the animation/art is usually done well by mad house. 


Sound: The Opening was great this season (I've liked all the openings so far). Not to many noticeable OST though. The ending was also great again. Because of the lack of amazing OST i'll rate sound a seven. 


Character: I'll keep this one quick because this review is getting long. The best thing about overlord in my opinion to be honest would have to be the characters. The Characters of Nazarick are mostly great. Most have great personalities that are extremely unique. Its sad we didn't get to see to much of them this season. The side/ support characters from Carne village and E-Rantel are well written and are extremely likable (I was always rooting for them even in the battle against Ains). To Sum this up before I go on a rant about how each character is amazing, the support character's growth, likability, and a real feel to them make Overlords character great.   


Overall: Even with its small flaws Overlord is a great series to get into and season three was my favorite season so far. If you love fantasy anime where there are multiple plots with overpowered done right then I highly recommend this show to you. Watching Overlord every Tuesday was a treat after a long day. Hopefully Mad house can work on another season soon (One punch man needs to come out first though).  


Thanks so much, this was my first review hopefully it didn't suck.

Overlord seasons 1 and 2 were pretty enjoyable.  They had some flaws, but overall still pretty fun.
Season 3 just has felt a little "meh".  Why?  It feels like they used the "I'm horribly overpowered" cliche of the series too much this season.  It was present in the first few seasons, but this season has largely been Gown and crew basically mopping the floor with unfortunate humans with very little sense of suspense. 
Plus what made seasons 1 and 2 more interesting was the character building which it felt was a lot more lacking this season.  But even if we aretalking about the fighting aspect the best fight of the series so far was back in Season 1 with the final fight of the season (won't name who vs who for spoilers sake) and the fight against Clementine more so because she was someone you wanted to hate. 


Plus the CG has been much more egregious this season.  Like it's there in front of your face where you can clearly see the poor animation.  That quality of animation would be fine for background characters, but this was entire sequences where the CG model was the action item.


In addition, 3 seasons in and we still have yet to answer the mysteries left by the first season of the show.  


It's not a bad show, but it's just not as fun as the first two seasons were.

To be honest, i am quite a bit disapointed with the anime, I know there is a budget problem, but even so to use that cringy CGI in the episode 11 is just a hideous crime to me as a fan, i don't think they should have made it traditional for i know it is reaaaaly hard, but still what they made is just too lazy. Also i understand how much the industry is nearly like a slave labour at times which makes the japanese animation market so hard to florish again, so take my complaints with a bit of salt and as not takingmuch into account the hardships of the workplace, this is a criticism or rant solely as a fan. 


So, here is some of my insight on the score i gave:


Story 7(anime) 10(LN):

UNfortunate as it is, compacting 3 volumes in 13 episodes is bound to hurt the overall story, it is boudn to feel rushed and give space for more important information, i get that specially in a novel that gives so much focus to it's internal diallogues and small detais. But to give the first 5 episodes to volume 8 and only 3 for volume 7 is just a dumb mistake, it shows that they tried to play funny and make it more heartwarming even thought the focus of this novel is not that. 

It seems as if the studio believes we would prefer this way, even though volume 7 is one of the best in the whole series for it shows how cruel Ainz can be and the sad conseuquences of his choices, it was so good because it was tragic.


Art 6:

This is pretty obvious why i gave a 6, the CGI is getting out of control, it's "horribleness" peaks in episode 11, which could have been done much better.

I don't mind using CGI for battles as it is indeed hard to make so many soldiers in a war, but look at Maria The Virgin,as far as i remember they didn't used it or used very little yet the battles were well made for they gave focus to few soldiers when giving us so pretty combat, you can use CGI  when showing large formations moving rather than that awful rag doll bashing, jesus make a close up when they clash so to make the fight look better, we would see some good individual fights and be satisfied. 


Sound 9: The sounds in the anime are awesome, the opening song is as iconic as the season 1, it fits the madness of the story and it's characters, most of it's sound effects are well timed and made altought it does suffer a bit for me sometimes, either because it changes too fast or the sound effects play when silence would have been better, to give a more misterious effect, but this is a minor detail.


Character 8(anime) 10(LN): Of course, the characters fortunatelly continue the same crazy people from Nazaric we all know, and Ainz misunderstanding... Just priceless.

But the anime does suffer a lot form the lack of detail in it's minor character and even some of it's main ones.

Arche for example came out in the anime as just a bit likeble, (she barelly was the focus) they cut off the debt collector scenes, the detais of her inner thoughs her interactions with her group, the detais of their unity, and even the reason some of their reason for being who they were, which were pretty relateble. Instead they gave more wacth time for the villagers... sigh... Even though Arche is the best selling point of the whole Arc. 


Enjoyment: 7(anime) : The fact they i kept seeing the small detais that were cut or the cringy CGI kept me from enjoying the anime fully, i could not enjoy it as i should because of these great let downs and the fact that i knew full well how important these details were, (i've read the 12 volumes about 6 times i am not kidding) .

The bad decision to give the 8th volume, the most boring of the 3 adapted, a great focus on the start just made me really angry and sad, Mad House made a injustice to Overlord here.


Overall 7: The anime wasn't bad per say, but it is far from 8.40. i was actually even thinking of giving it a 6 because of how sad i became after seing one of my favorite novels being butchered like this, but in the end i have to admit it wasn't that bad, but it could have been a master piece.

this Season Covers 2 of the best volumes  yet they choose to elevate the most boring volume in the entire LN, this to me shows 2 things:

 1-the studio does not know one bit of what it's audience wants, 2- they were too afraid to place a bet in the 7th volume because of it's "controvesy", so they decided to give it less focus the minimize our attachment to the arc.

So in the end they killed what could have been a masterpiece of a season.

This anime really butchered all the good parts about the novel. The first season was pretty good, the second season was so-so but still managed to include most of the important parts despite many flaws, but this season was horrible if you've read the novel because it's impossible to not compare them. 
The first few episodes were decent enough and did a decent job of showing volume 8, albeit missing many parts and exchanging stuff that shouldn't have been exchanged. But things went south from there. It's very obvious, painfully so, that they wanted to force themselves to cram 3 volumes worth of material into13 episodes without actually being able to do so. This resulted in cuts everywhere. So many good parts were ruined. 


The art were also average at best, the monsters here generally resembled kids anime ones, be it neuronist, the trolls or the naga who all looks severely lacking in so many ways. They have no details whatsoever, as if the animators just didn't care to give any effort on the matter and made them as plain as possible. Simple colors that might as well have been filled in with a paint bucket tool and without any real features to them. It really removes from entertainment when something that is supposed to be cool is reduced to a children's monster drawing. They also conveniently excluded things like the soul eater mounts for the last battle, not to mention that instead of summoning 500 monsters and entering in a cool way, he came with just a handful ones. It's so disappointing I don't even know where to start, everything is ridiculously underwhelming and there's no sense of immersion whatsoever because everything was dumbed down to oblivion.


As for the parts that were ruined other than the last battle, let's just mention a few things like how almost all the cool and interesting scenes were removed to save time and if they weren't, they were so toned down that they should've just removed them altogether if they weren't going to do it properly. Things gets worse after the first few episodes when they start to rush everything. Enri and company's dinner and events when visiting nazarick were completely glossed over, ainz suddenly finds himself in the capital of the empire without any prior notice and then he's just suddenly hired by the adventurer teams without a proper set-up, then we skip his mock battle with the worker and instantly teleport to nazarick and the entire journey inside was extremely boring as people just died pretty much instantly, chatting between characters are skipped and so are many events leading up to their deaths, we just quickly get teleported around to each individual as they meet their ends without explanation on the matter. Ainz first meeting with fluder, which was originally pretty cool, was summarized in hindsight in a few seconds of animation at the end of an episode without any of the dialogue.


They're essentially butchering the original content completely until we're left with only the absolute main parts of the story, the bare minimum required to make any sense whatsoever and move the story forward. This leaves us with a lackluster anime that lacks everything it should have. It lacks the character development, it lacks the interesting parts, it's void of everything and anything that made overlord a good story. At this point, it's just a dumbed down piece of garbage that isn't worth watching even if you loved the overlord novel. It's not immersive, it's not interesting, the art is skimped on, the story is rushed and even an average anime would do a better job at being interesting and entertaining. 


If they can't do it properly with 3 volumes for a 13 episode season, they should cut it down to 2 volumes for a 13 episode season, that way they can include the things that actually makes this into a story instead of just a lackluster and subpar isekai story that barely has anything in common with the overlord novel except for the characters and the overarching plot developments. The plot points are there(like this or that happened), but everything that was supposed to flesh it out is missing. It's like a human without any organs or a pizza without any toppings, essentially just the framework, the dough. Everything that makes it good isn't here.


It's sad when adaptations screw things up to this extent. Not even someone who hasn't read the novel would feel like this is good enough to watch because it simply lacks anything compelling and unique about it, rather, it's subpar to the normal stuff you find everywhere.


Oh, I'll just quickly mention that the overall art is horrible in more ways than just being of shitty single colors, the choppy low-quality 3d crap is ruining WAY too much of the cool moments by looking like trash. This show truly failed in every way imaginable. Screams of cutting the budget in every way imaginable. Season 2 was horrible, but this took it to another level of bad. It defecates on the original story and everything it should be in order to grab some easy cash because people like the novel and the first season was a great success...

I've talked about Overlord twice before. The first series was average with some good ideas they weren't doing anything with. The second series moved up to good by giving some actual tension. Now we're looking at the third series. Which may or may not be improved. To recap the story thus far, Ainz Ooal Gown was a high level player in an online game. When the game shut down, he somehow found himself in a new world with all the high-powered NPCs he & his friends created. Now he's trying to navigate that world while also commanding more power than anyone else seems to. Variouspeople are being caught up in his schemes. 


Story:


Continuing from the last series, Nazarick has gained control of the Kingdom's underworld and taken a bunch of their populace for horrific experiments. In this series we open with the small village Ainz rescued in the first series, Carne, where two great beasts are about to invade. Meanwhile, the Empire has heard about the tomb of Nazarick and is about to send a bunch of mercenaries to explore it. Which will certainly end well for them. 


The first big issue with this series is just that most of the plot threads that get some kind of resolution have really obvious resolutions. Take the Carne village part. There's no tension because we find out, even before any fighting begins, that the Nazarick maid, Lupisregina, is going to e watching out for every village character who's developed enough for you to potentially give a shit about. Then there are the mercenary workers. It's obvious when they describe their job that they're heading for Nazarick. It's equally obvious that things will not end well for any of them. So, when they try to give you reasons to care it doesn't work very well since you already see them as fodder.


On some more positive notes, the series does set up some pretty compelling things. Honestly, I get the sense that the fourth series will be more interesting when it builds off of this. I will also say that the whole final arc of this has a lot of strong moments. Which I shan't spoil until I review series IV and recap it. I will also say that the scenes with the Nazarick crew just taking quiet moments to relax and act like normal friends are pretty great. 


Characters:


There's not much in terms of advancing the characters or in fleshing them out. Pretty much what we get is carried over from the prior series. The main new characters we get are some interchangeable goblins, the fodder & some Empire characters who are mainly notable for the political intrigue they represent rather than for what little they have you can call personalities. 


The series tries to do what the second did by basing the tension off of the secondary characters who are actually at risk, but I've already been over why it doesn't work with this one. 


Art:


There's not much to say about the Overlord artwork that I haven't already, to be honest. The series continues to have strong character designs, action sequences that are quite good in spite of generally being very one-sided & nice backgrounds. It's also worth noting that this is a series where the CG can stand out but it ends up contributing to make certain monsters look otherworldly. Which works fairly well.


Also, good on Madhouse for managing to have an episode where the characters go to a bath house without making it fan-servicey. That's not something I can usually credit the studio with. 


Sound: 


The acting continues to be nicely done. Sakurai Takahiro has a somewhat major role in this one and he's very good at what he does. I look forward to the obligatory scene where his character cross dresses. Hirakawa Daisuke & Ichimichi Mao also do really well. Of course, the major characters continue to be well acted. Katou Masayuki, Hino Satoshi, Hara Yumi, Katou Emiri & the others are all good at what they do. 


In general, Katayama Shuji's soundtrack works nicely for the tone and atmosphere. I'm a bit more mixed on the theme tunes. I don't think they're bad but I also don't really want to listen to them and usually ended up skipping over them. 


Ho-yay:


There's a little bit. Shalltear mentions that she's only slept with women. We also meet Nazarick's torturer who's basically the monster version of Fire Emblem from Tiger & Bunny. I guess whoever created him thought it would be funny if that character type was torturing people in more ways than just by existing. 


Areas of Improvement:


The Mission to Nazarick should have been more obfuscated. A part of the problem with giving a shit about the workers as characters is that we immediately know, from the instant they're introduced, that they're fodder. So, maybe give us the time spent trying to builds them up before that particular bombshell drops rather than after. 

Give the goblins some distinct personalities. Pretty much all that distinguishes these guys is that they look slightly different. But they all basically act the same. Which means we don't really care when they're in danger. 

Give us a bit more of the Nazarick crew's interactions. Like I said, that segment may be short but it's great. 


Final Thoughts:


Overally, Overlord III is not as strong as the second series. While it does have its moments, particularly the final arc & the whole Nazarick relaxation interlude, it also suffers a bit from the same issue that plagued the first series. There's a lack of any real tension. We know that the Carne village situation is going to end well for the characters we even slightly care about. We know what's going to happen with the workers and we don't care. I would still say this instalment is stronger than the first series. It's pretty decent. So, I'll give it a 6/10.

(7/10) to me because
Story : Its kinda lack and not so much but they did their very best for all the details they need to geared it up in next sequel. 
Art: Let's accept it that Overlord franchise have a good art in their anime. It still give us the high definition of watching anime, hope they keep their production until the end.
Sounds, Character and Enjoyment: I think those three is still the same for me. Quality of sounds is great. Character development in each specific characters are good, even tho their is a heck of characters in this anime. Overlord franchise still manage tocome up some idea of how they evolved  their personas and characteristic with Ains as their highest authority. I think it's deserved to be in top although the content of the whole season is not really appealing to me compare to the first two seasons. My advice is don't expect too much in this season three just enjoy this anime because the story so far is important for the next sequel.

TLDR; Overlord FINALLY starts getting somewhere.
I enjoyed the first season of Overlord, despite the fact that it felt the plot meandered all over the place and took forever to get somewhere. Overlord II only got worse at this, with the first half of the season being about characters we had never met before, and trialling their struggles, with only minor appearances by the main cast (and fringe members of the main cast at that).
Overlord III feels like at last the author has spent enough time world building and character building, and is finally getting down to brass tacks. No new major characters are introduced, insteadopting to spend more time on developing existing characters. 


It does feel a little like the author is writing himself into a corner with Ains' power level though. Ains can easily beat the best warriors in the present world without even breaking a sweat and describes them as being infinitely worse than any top level player characters. Canonically, Nazarick was built by ~40 of his guild members pouring all their IRL money into a P2W computer game, and it was once besieged by 1500 PCs from top PvP guilds who were unable to take it. Ains is now in charge of not only Nazarick, not only the combined wealth and magical items of the entire guild, but also the entire dungeon worth of NPCs which are 100% loyal to him and now are able to think and act.

The only two ways I can see Ains being threatened in future series are either at least 1000 players drop out of nowhere and make a concerted effort to fight him (which will never happen) or he will be threatened by clerical problems such as the difficulties of controlling a vast empire you cannot possibly oversee all at once. Aside from this, there is literally nothing to stop him from overthrowing the entire world in the first couple of episodes in S4.


I do however feel I need to make special mention of the art style. The majority of the anime is done in the old-fashioned style most anime is done with. A few scenes are done with CGI though, and it is incredibly obvious and incredibly jarring and 4th wall breaking. Very very disappointing they couldn't spend a little extra money on animating the CGI instead and easily the worst part of the series.


Oh, and also at one point Ains has to pick a title for himself to distance himself from normal kings and rulers and show that he is greater than them, destined to rule over them, like an Overlord if you will.

And he picks Sorcerer King. What the hell.

This was hands down the best season of Overlord, and the second half makes this an anime of the year candidate for me.  FINALLY, Ains and the Nazarick crew are acting like TRUE villains.  No killing people and then bringing them back.  No pretending to be villainous just to do something noble, later. No killing people who are evil themselves and deserve it. No caveats to keep the Nazarick crew looking somewhat heroic or  like anti-heroes.  They are just full of straight up, epic, merciless, villainous behavior in the second half of this season.     
I alreadyenjoyed Overlord because I love animes where OP characters flex on weaker characters and everyone is in awe of their power.  But, I was always disappointed with how they didn't really seem like true bad guys, but you come to expect that from animes as creators don't want their main cast to be unlikable to the masses.  I didn't expect more, but boy did this season surprise.  Very rarely do you get great anime that shows things from a pure villain's perspective and Overlord has finally become that.  


What I love especially is that it's Ains who has become truly ruthless, and as such, his subordinates follow suit.  Ains was already someone I liked as a character, but his callous ruthlessness in this season, makes him my favorite character in this anime, which has a lot of cool characters.  (I could do with some more Lupisregina and Cocytus in season 4, though.).  


Also, I have to point out the epic intro, as well.  That Voracious intro really hit well and fit the anime.  


I really can't wait to see what season 4 has in store.  I imagine it's probably about time for whoever took over Shaltear Bloodfallen to come on the scene.  Someone has to emerge to become a true threat to Nazarick at this point.

only problem with the series is they cram/cut 3 books into only 13 episodes per season.  They need 24 minimum for each season.  Their is a enough information in the books to make it as lengthy as one piece.

Enri's goblin general horn's, considered a trash drop in the game of Yggdrasil, have a hidden power that is unlocked by meeting the 3 requirements of the goblin general. The second arc is the invaders of the tomb arc.  We are introduced to the worker group foresight.  Workers outside the adventure guild and only do it for money.  Ainz uses Fluder to set up an invasion of Nazarick.  He even bribes them but they charge in the tomb so Ainz sees no reason to eliminate them.  Most people actually care about the foresight group but they meet their end in terrible ways.

1) test out the defenses of Nazarick using the lowest amount of expenses because they only have a finite amount of Yggdrasil gold.

2) Give nazarick justification to force the Empire to support them.

3) Introduces some of area guardians and terrors of Nazrick.  Death is a mercy.


The 3rd arc the caster of destruction arc.

Starts off with Emperor being forced to go to Nazarick or his country will be destroyed.  Ainz uses him to bring the reeztize kingdom out to fight.  So he can show a portion of the power of Nazrick to scare the world and to establish the sorcerer kingdom.


Politics behind the nobility/royal dispute in the kingdom and the Empire secretly trying to inspire an alliance against AInz.  The safest way he know how is to support Ainz to figure out his power.  Just Ainz is way stronger then anythiing he ever dreamed about.


Brings carne village back when Prince Barbro plans to siege, kill and kidnap to force Ainz to stop his war.  The villagers loyalty is so extreme that they fight back.  Out of desperation to prevent the the women and children from being killed.  Enri uses the 2nd horn to summon a goblin troop again.  however instead of 19 goblins.  She summons a professional army of 5,000 experienced goblins.  Some of them being stronger than death knights.  She developed her skills as a commander, good relations with the goblins and in peril by a sizable force.


The arc ends with the kingdom and empire waiting for ainz to show up.  The kingdom is ready to retreat when Ainz uses a super tier spell to instantly kill 70,000 soldiers.  using their corpses to summon 5 dark young.  which are level 90.  Then he stomps the remaining 180,000 soldiers into a full route of the kingdoms forces.


Gazef challenges Ainz to a duel.  level 100 vs a level 30.  Ainz shows deep respect to Gazef by making his death instantaneous.  He wanted to have Gazef as a subordinate but Gazef planned his death to show the true power of Ainz.


Ends with Ainz taking over Erantel fortress city and the surronding land establishing the sorcerer kingdom.  ready to manipulate the world to bend its knee in the future books/seasons.

Story: Good
Overall best isekai story yet. Revolving NOT ONLY the protagonist and his henchmen (like EVERY other isekai ever that only focus on the stupid OP-ness of it's main character while still leveling up to infinite strength) BUT ALSO involving other characters in the world (although it's just like 2 countries).
As you all that read a lot of isekai manga/novel can agree with me, isekai is power fantasy story usually showing OP MC in quest of saving the world while leveling up with it's merry harem party facing a lot of trials along the way. But unlike most isekai manga/anime, Overlord took a little bitchange in the genre (if you can call isekai as it's own genre now) making it very unique and stand out compared to other isekai, which is:- making MC and the gang already OP as fuck since the beginning. This series shows only a glimpse of the power of Ainz and the gang, showing fractions of their ridiculous OP powers without any progress of leveling up. So what to do with all the powers that the MC and the gang possess? Instead of guarding the world for everlasting peace, how about conquering the world for themselves?


What make this story good? The answer is it's different with any other isekai. While most isekai focus on good-natured MC-and-friends leveling up and travelling the world to fight demon king, Overlord show the progress and how this apathetic-of-anyone-useless Demon king itself taking over the world little by little through schemes and sheer power while the humans of the worlds also got their own hidden agenda. While this show lean more to the 'serious' side, it also got bits of funny scenes that genuinely nice.


Art: Fair.

Same like any other anime production. So-so quality with generic bad CGI.


Sound: Fair.

Same like any other anime production. Nothing stand out much.


Character: Good.

Each characters in this anime are interesting. From the party of Ainz to the lowly humans, all got unique characteristic that shows how each of them suit in the scenario of each arc. From manipulating and deceiving characters to dumb-honest characters and stupid annoying characters, everyone has their own purpose.

The only thing I don't like is the lack of character introduction and their exposure for some characters. You need to read the manga and the novel for that.


Enjoyment: Good.

Very much enjoyable if you ever get sick of generic isekai with OP MC with harem of women that only revolve around ecchi things. 


Overall: Good.

Can't wait for more of this anime story.


Side note:

If you are the kind that want to watch a generic isekai anime with leveling up things in term of strength and acquiring infinite new skills, new 'titles' that will never be useful for the story, with friendship power that overcome everything, fast pace, ecchi harem all episode go watch other anime. Overlord is not for you.

What started as a typical gamer isekai story has become one of the greatest shows I've ever seen. Even in season one, this show impressed me by how it implemented an internally consistent magic system, where there's none of the "I surpassed my maximum power" nonsense. The strategies used in battle and the negotiation tactics implemented create very realistic situations which are difficult to produce in fiction. With much of the story focusing on side characters who lived in the world before Ains Ooal Gown appeared, it crafts an image of what the world is like before, during, and after its encounters with Ains OoalGown. With each decision made by Ains Ooal Gown, we're introduced to questions. Are the people in this world NPC's or humans, deserving of rights? Is it wrong to subjugate people by force if the ruler will rule justly? How can you appear just while also appearing strong and uncompromising? And, with no ultimately defined goal, how would you act with near-infinite power? These questions arise naturally within the world, and this fact makes the story believable and immersive in a way that I've rarely seen. This rareness of depth is why I determined that the show deserves a full 10/10 score (a score I don't give lightly). Clearly a lot of time and care went into the creation of this world and story.

This season in particular has effectively cemented my continuing disappointment in the show. Don't get me wrong, its a decent time, but nowhere near the enjoyment and pacing I remember from the first season. The biggest issue I believe stems from a double edge knife; the character focus. The series does a great job maintaining relevance of the side character that I have come to appreciate when the deeper connections begin to unfold. That being said, it also results in a lot of waste and pretentious scenes. In the final scene, the dual could have been shortened tremendously with respect to the dialogue. It wasnot necessary to draw out the encounter as long as they did and I felt that a bulk of the episode in particularly was bloated and unremarkable. I feel like a lot of the episodes in the show can be described that way. For binge watching it is less noticeable since you can just move at your own pace and watch what happens next but when we are waiting for episodes I wish I could say I was satisfied with what I held my breath for.

Ainz was always evil. He runs a guild that is an evil Guild, he himself is considered "evil" under the alignment. He loses the ability to care about death and only really cares about those under his command, yet he still retains compassion and understanding for those who are beneath him-which in all honesty is just about everyone.
But hey let's negative reviewers seem to want, one thing I agreed on at one point but now think it's right is that Ainz should be MOREdecisive. He shouldn't second guess, doubt, and otherwise feel sorry for himself. But around the point of reading book 11 I really started to like him as a character. Let's say Ainz is decisive, let's say Ainz is decisive and he wants to stay within Nazarick. 


End of series, Ainz stays is Nazarick forever.


Lets say Ainz is decisive and wants to crush humanity, and the world. 


End of series Ainz crushes humanity and the world. There is no one who can stand up to Ainz. The fun is in watching him struggle to maintain a growing empire even though he is just an average guy much outmatched by those around him in terms of Administration Ability, Intelligence. While being generally disliked simply because he himself is an undead. Ainz has strokes of brilliance, especially towards 12-13 in the Light Novels.

When I first watched Overlord I, I never expected it to get a second season. It had been out for about 2 years when I first heard of it and I had never really thought much about it after I finished watching it. I enjoyed it, and was, admittedly, rather disappointed at the lack of any follow-up, especially considering that it didn't really feel like a show that was born to fail. The people who made this show wanted to make more and they had the source material to do it. But it just died, like so many others in the genre do. I eventuallyconceded that this series was doomed to join the pile, accompanied by shows like No Game No Life and Log Horizon.


So you can imagine my surprise when, all of a sudden, Overlord II is announced, added to the database, and scheduled to premiere in about a month. I don't think the word 'utter-shock' could be considered an exaggeration of my reaction.. and yet, I don't think the word disappointment can be considered a misrepresentation of my review. It was rather bad. Not super-bad. Just bad. And from there, I was sure that would be the death of overlord as a franchise...


But hold the phone, because before season 2's corpse even had a chance to go cold, season 3 blew down the door and declared it would be out in 3 months time. Pause for breath. Take in the silence...

FUCKING. WHAT?!?!

You're telling me that this product, which was, in the end, not even that poorly received by the fans, is getting ANOTHER SEASON? NOW? Despite its arguable lack of originality, poor taste in humor, lazy animation, directionless storytelling and regardless of the fact that there are SO MANY OTHER TYPES of this very same concept that ARN'T getting another season?

REALLY?

Maybe my anger is unfounded. Maybe I'm going a bit too far by insinuating that this show is innately awful. Or that the quality difference between Season 1 and 2 was all that sizable. And again, If I have learned anything about anime it's that: first impressions almost never accurately represent the quality of the end product. But Jesus Christ man... Jesus fucking Christ...




Overlord III has sealed the deal and officially labels its franchise as the fastest to diminish in quality on an episode by episode basis. There is nothing here that warrants any praise outside of *maybe* the ability to at least remember the last 2 seasons of story. Everything else is either done poorly or has been done better in a previous season. It's genuinely a shame that it's come to this point and if we EVER get Overlord IV, then I can only assume that some super-fan is funding this pitiful husk of a project.


The animation is absolutely the prime example of this. In Season 1 and 2 there were a few bits of CGI that, while executed poorly, never really ruined the experience. They were almost always used exclusively on the undead monsters which, conveniently (and canonically), managed to fit their choppy and rigid style of movement. In season 3, its almost as if the 2D artists ran away and everyone else was left to make the show like it was some kind of 1990s south park episode except with the help of the guy who was training to be a CGI animator for yogurt adverts. Whenever something is made to look impressive it simply fails. But let's give credit where credit is due, the 2D art is still leaps and bounds ahead of the 3D mess (I hesitate to call it art). Unfortunately, to only make things worse, CGI is 5x more present than it was before (and in some cases even replaces parts where 2D art would ALWAYS look better). Its gut wrenching to look at and utterly ruined what should have been the most climactic episode in the entire trilogy.


Moving on, the story is just tiresome at this point. We have now established that our MC is decked out, unbeatable and unfathomably powerful. So why, WHY, are we going around in circles by still trying to prove that? There are 3 arcs in this season. The first one is boring and we won't even mention it (because, if the lizards proved anything, we (all together now) "♫ Don't-give-a fuck-about-the-nor-mal-peo-ple ♫"). The second one is another "build up a character(s) or scenario and let MC stomp it all in one fell swoop", yeah, that one that we've done about 4 times now. Cool. The third arc actually has content, it follows on from the events of the second arc (except not in a way that excuses the wasted episodes of character development - even if you were just trying to highlight how evil everyone can be, it was pointless), From a story perspective, it's actually progressive and is a step in the right direction. However, more than any other arc in the trilogies history, it is totally ruined by the terrible CGI and pointless pride that apparently has to come from every sword wielder in a fantasy story - ever. It hurts me to think that removing any one thing would improve the show drastically, but it's all there anyway, amassing to be the shittiest stir-fry of bad practices and botched jobs I've ever written about (apart from THAT ONE SHOW we don't talk about).


Furthermore, where are all the good characters? Where's the fun butler dude or the demon or the big ant ~thing~. Why are we stuck with an endless onslaught of nameless maids and chipper blonde WANKERS that didn't even need to exist? Why is that what we're getting when all we really want is to see more of the characters that you've already spent time developing? This show has an awful issue of always starting from square one whenever it forgets what it was doing (which, apparently, seems to occur every 6 or so episodes) and if you couldn't tell from the previous words I went and wrote, It pisses me off.



I am really disappointed with the direction that Overlord has taken these past few months. I don't know if the studio is overworked, there was a disaster at the office, or even if the source material isn't up to scratch with the content that originally got the anime greenlit; but there is definitely a detrimental difference in quality. If I were asked, I would tell them to take a break. You CAN try Overlord IV (if you must), but don't push it out 3 months from now. Give it 9 months, give it a year. Clear your minds or clear your desk because the only reasons this has gone on for as long as it has is because, somehow, we don't have anything similar that is better.


Thank you for reading...
