Ok, this show is not meant to be a cerebral experience. It does not have a weighty philosophy or ethical dilemma or even a who-dun-it atmosphere. It is not a meticulous character study or a depiction of humanity. It is a liberating experience for all the MMORPG lovers that brings out their inner God complex vicariously. It does tug and scrape at your conscience (intentionally) to reveal the true nature of this God complex. The protagonist is a leader of bad guys. He is an average human gamer thrust into this role of this supreme overlord. Well, as most RPG gamers can relate, we allseek to achieve such a powerful status while killing all the minions and sacrificing NPCs to gain levels. 


Story: 7


As Momonga, the protagonist starts adjusting to his new life as the Ovrelord, he feels himself losing his humanity gradually. The people in the new world are all just pawns for extending his power and understanding of the unfamiliar place nad its potential. His actions become more calculated and cautious like that of a Mob boss.


We don't really know much about the NPCs who get slain by our characters in the games and so we don't mind slaying them. But in here , the show gives us deep insights into their background and struggles they face in their life up until the point they get killed by the protagonists. This show illustrates how video games subtly desensitize us to violence. To Momonga, the people are pawns he needs to improve his power in a video game while we as viewers feel empathetic to their life and the situation which makes it harder for us to actually root for the protagonist. I like the fact that the story has these neat layers to it instad of devolving into a rambling tale of easy conquest of a supreme overlord.


World Building: 9


This show has is a visual and visceral treat for all fantasy lovers. From the magic system to different races inhabiting the world it simply is breathtaking. It resembles a MMORPG game very much in this aspect and it is glorious. The scope for further development is infinite due to the same reason.


Art and Animation: 10


Splendid! Madhouse is as outstanding as ever in this department. I loved every frame and every design (well give or take a few). I couldn't help admiring how beautiful the art and animation was especailly during the battle scenes


Sound: 7


It's alright. Nothing that really stands out although it is composed to suit the atmosphere very well.  Occasionally, there are a few good scores which nicely complement the beautiful visuals



Characters: 8


What can I say either you like em or you don't. The characters are, at a first glance, pretty simple and one dimensional ( save a few). HOWEVER they are damn interesting and enjoyable and subtly grow over the episodes. It is like observing NPC in the games starting to evolve gradually as they learn and adapt from theri experiences in the new world. I believe this is also one of the aspects of the story that the author aims to address as we see Momonga constantly making observations on how his subordinates change over time.


My one gripe is that most of the female characters were portrayed as evil, manipulative or bitchy. Some even looked a lot alike with blond hair. Almost all of them are smitten by Momonga. I wish the author had included some variety in his character design for the girls department instead of making the anime look like a cheap harem show.


Conclusion:


I really enjoy this show from the first episode in Season 1 to the latest one. I could hardly stop binging on all the episodes. This might not be for people who are easily put off by overpowered protagonist with an evil side. The show does not dwell on the MC being morally conflicted by his actions or longing for his past life (which makes sense given he lost a part of his humanity) It does deliver fully on the entertainment scale with every developing event piquing our interest.


If you liked Hellsing Ultimate, Berserk or even One-Punch Man, do pick this one up without hesitation

The top review already address most of my issues on this anime but let me share a scene that ruins overlord for me or at least the MC. Momonga/Ainz whatever you want to call him is the bread and butter of the show. Whenever he's on screen the hype just goes of the charts. So this all powerful overlord sets up an arena to fight some adventurers from the thieves guild... let that sink in really hard... all powerful... overlord... sets up an arena... to fight some adventurers from the thieves guild... and for what? What was the point of setting up this arena, gettingyour butt up from your throne, trying so hard to make the fight look fair and for what? So they steal some gold big deal! Even I wouldn't fight this guys because it's not worth it. Let my servants fight these ants. You set up this arena that has no audience, all survivors killed (Dead men tell no tales) the servants are the only witness? So you want your servants to think your edgy? So the reason is that "Just because he wanted to" because he can... ooh Ainz how could you stoop soo low. Ainz will never be the same in my eyes, I've lost all my respect for him. Fight someone your own size!

Well...this was a big disappointment. This is my first review (and last)  for the Overlord saga.  I will briefly explain why I think you should take your money and run by not watching this season. 
Story 6/10
We have an "OP" Character in a world that just can't produce an antagonist to match his power, basic plot so far. Usually this characters hold back their "divine" power because they know that their power is knowledge, so why does Ains really on the speculation of his servants to make a move? It completely differs from the other seasons in which the story progresses around othercharacters aside Ains. It makes no sense that the main goal is World Domination when we know the world is dominated because no one can survive a fight with Ains. 


Character 4/10

Ever seen Star Wars Episode 3 iconic scene where Obi Wan tells Anakin "You became the thing you swore to destroy"? Well, this season is that phrase times 10. Same characters on Ains side and a few character developments on the human side. 


The only "major" change comes from Ains (and not a self indulged change) when he gives a damn about the world by trying to seize it all. It gives the character an " I have nothing better to do" attitude. 


Art and Sound 7/10

Pretty basic for the series. It didn't set a new standard for the series, but giving it a seven for the giant goat like creatures that gave the anime a little sense of creativity. 


Enjoyment 3/10

I've seen worse but also have seen much better anime than this, both of the genre and not. 


I will definitely think twice next time a new season comes out. Do you agree?

Overlord S3 marks the return of the Undead Ainz Ooal Gown sama to the Tomb Of Nazareth.  After a lukewarm S2, S3 manages to live up the hype (The Hype is Real!).
The story is fun.  The overpowered Main Character is on a completely different scale than all the other characters.  There are not many good guys in the series, especially not Ainz.  The first episode is kind of a filler episode with funny moments.  The humor is on point, though it gets dark a lot time (gruesome deaths of innocents/good guys).  The characters may not be as deep assome other series, but the absolute freakish nature of the anime allows to overlook that.  While people complain about the CG especially if army units, I don't think that takes away much from the anime.  The opening track is really peppy and good.  Compared to the second season, this one is much better paced and leads to real story developments.

Somehow I give it an 8, but I not sure that it really is. Maybe just a 7. 
In my opinion, this is an anime with a huge potential but it is not coming out. The first season got me enthusiastic about the concept, the second season was pretty mediocre and even though this season was better it still wasn't great. Perhaps it is the manga (did not read it)?
If I would have to guess, I would blame the weak story/tension build up. I feel it is stopping every season at the point where you can see (the next peak) but without being on one.Moreover, the story feels slow, because they try to be thorough, but by the time I am getting captivated the season is over. I would propose a 52 episode course to get this really off the ground.

Boy, oh boy. Another season of Overlord. I loved the first season, but, I just couldn't get into the second one. 
But now, here I am. Once again to have fallen in love with the story of the overpowered undead Ainz Ooal Gown and the beautiful intro of the third season of 
'Overlord'.
****There might be spoilers****
Story
As I said, this series is about that overpowered skeleton-like 'monster' called Lord Ainz. In this season, he is starting to take control over the world, which he surely can do with ease. 
But another part of the story is taken by Enri, the leader of the small Carne Village,which is also under the control of the protagonist.


It is really amazing to see a story from the view of the 'evil' side of it.

I always thought Ainz wouldn't hurt the humans, but boy, I was so wrong.

Only one magical spell to whipe out an entire army - leaving almost no one surviving.


Art 


Not much to say about it, it's a nicely animated anime with no flaws I can argue about.


Sound


Well, the music in this was - how should I say - absolutely amazing!


The intro "VORACITY" by MYTH＆ROID was so good - it'd be a reason to keep watching even if the anime wasn't good at all. 

I love it. That's all I can say about it.


Character


Well, it's the same as it has been before, really, really evil beings trying to rule the world against the humans, who begin to fall into despair when they see their powers. But the protagonist also leaves those, who accept him, in peace. So he's not just a monster killing everyone it sees because I think, with his powers, that'd be really boring as he'd whipe out humanity within a few days.


I loved this season and I am exited for the next one.


9/10

I like to call Overlord the "Successful Sword Art Online", mainly because it takes what Sword Art tries to do and actually does it successfully. 
Both stories are fundamentally the same; they trap a veteran of the game inside the world of the game and we get to watch how they abuse their power/wit in order to beat the game, or conquer the world in Ains' case. The reason Overlord succeeds is because it's actually interesting. 
Build up is an important factor in most story telling, generally the bigger the build up the more exciting it is when things actually happen. It took Overlord 3seasons of introducing characters, various locations and factions, differences in power levels of the characters and other important info, and it definitely paid off with that season finale. On the contrary, SAO only took 4 episodes to try and achieve the same effect. It didn't work out so well. \n
In essence, Overlord is how the story telling of an overpowered cheat character should be done.

This is the third season of Overlord.  While I'd normally recommend the third season of anything to someone who already likes the series, I'm not sure I can.  The animation relies heavily on CGI.  Heavily.  Too heavily.
While CGI can be acceptable, even fine or good in some series depending on implementation - look at Gundam Unicorn - here it's awful.  It's lazy.  It's not even trying to hide its laziness.  It's as if the animators are telling the audience "eh, whatever, you get the point."  Previous seasons have obviously CGI skeletons.  This season is far, farworse.  


The story is surprisingly good.  Pacing both within and between episodes felt good with only one or two hiccups.  Rarely did anything feel forced, rarely (though there is a particularly egregious example) did anything feel unnecessarily drawn out. 


The opening is probably my least favorite of Myth&Roid's work.  Sound within the anime itself is fine, serviceable, but nothing really noteworthy beyond "the opening is significantly worse than previous work by the same artist."


Character interaction, worldbuilding, and plot are the strong points here, don't go looking for technical achievement.

So quite the amount of people are giving this a not so well review. But personally, this show only gets better and better each season.
So you might see that I have a 9 out of 10 on this, but that's because I ended up calculating my average up. It's amazing though, and I recommend you watch this season as well as the other ones!
Story (8/10):
So the beginning of the show showed the comedic side of it, which was basically a "Welcome Back" for the returned audience. Really enjoyed that. But, then it started going into the plot of the season and..ehh..I .gotta admit that itwas a bit slow-pacing for me, I would say it was dragging it a bit too much. The way they introduced the new characters wasn't the best transition to the season, but I guess it's fine because most of them were in the show for a short amount of time, anyways. Otherwise, it's hella good. 


Art (7/10):


Most of the art is the typical amount for an "average" anime. Not too much detail, like the amount that Violet Evergarden had, but enough to see the outline of the characters. The animation's pretty typical, too. The CGI parts are a bit low quality and dated, but I mean, I guess it was easier making those skeletal creatures 3D than 2D for the artists. 


Sound (10/10)


Character's voice actors fit with the personality and the mood that is brought together with the character themselves. Music is amazing. Matches with the tone of the show and the chaotic appeal to the show as well. All I can say is that the music just keeps on getting better and better.


Characters (9/10)


My main problem with the show for the longest time was the amount of appearances of characters in a season. So grateful that they took that into account for this series, and they're starting to show more of the Nazarick characters. Especially Aura, since she's been my favorite character from the beginning. They only showed small clips of her for the first two seasons, but then in one of the episodes they showed more of her and her abilities. Even showed a shyness of her that wasn't really shown into the show. The only character I had a problem with was that character Jircniv Nix. He reminded me of one of those annoying pretty boys. Like each time he would pop up, I would skip it. I think they purposely made him annoying, but still, probably the most annoying character in Overlord.


Enjoyment (10/10)


The thing about this show, specifically this season, is that you're always surprised of the outcome. Each season, it's like you get everything you want: a bit of action, lots of fantasy, a bit of humor, and other things. There isn't usually a dull moment in the show, in my opinion. 


Overall (9/10)

Some minor things to fix in this season, otherwise its definitely worth watching. If you're at the end of this review, then thank you for reading my thoughts and what I had to say. I hope you consider this review effective or helpful in anyway. :)-

Some spoilers ahead but very minor!!!
As for  my grading "rules"
I  do not like to give really bad grades (the lowest I have given for a show is 4 or 5)  keep that in mind!
Overlord is probably my favorite isekai anime and i liked the last two seasons very much. But the thing which was a huge let down for me this season was the irredeemably bad CGI that they used in this season. Madhouse studio is absolutely MAD for using so bad CGI in this work. Overlords CGI has never been the best in the previous seasons but it has done itjob well enough. But these horrendous  plastic model CGI armies and those big thingys (if you have watched episode 12 you know what I mean) are almost just as bad as  bad as the CGI in the new Berserk franchise which I haven't even watched but the GIFs and clips from it are enough to tell me the quality of the CGI.

The last episode has not yet aired and I hope it is going to good and this is mostly rant about the bad CGI and it is sad to see so great story crumble down because Madhouse does not put enough budget to CGI. The good thing is that there is not like tons of CGI scenes.


As for the other aspects of the show..


Story: 9 (little more gore than the previous seasons but still good in my opinion)


Art: CGI: 1 or 2 but the rest animation and other art stuff is somewhere between 7 and 8 (really like the style of the show)


Sound: Between 7 and 8 (OP and ED are both really good but the rest of the sounds are pretty basic but still nothing to complain about)


Characters: 10 (Overlords strongest side is the characters, even the minor side characters are really well written)


Enjoyment: 7 (If the CGI was any better it would be 8 or 9)


Overall: 6 

Otherwise a great anime and a visual novel adaptation but the CGI is really bad

Overlord has its strength and weaknesses, but in the 3.rd one, it was nearly painful to watch 8 episodes of filler shit at the start, the last 5 episodes were pretty rock solid. In the overlord 3, there was way too much slice of life especially with totally irrelevant characters. The problem in here is the same what happens with MANY anime especially, it is trying too hard to please too many people and it kills the whole show away.
First 8 episodes: 3 :(
Last 5: 8 :)
too little too late, no matter how much water you drink, the bad taste stays in your mouth. 
Well,I like more serious shows anyway with no any childish nonsense; like berserk or goblin hunter in this category.

The more you watch this show the more you realize there is actually no plot and its just one op guy dicking on a bunch of low level trash. Honestly needed to have some resemblance of an antagonist to Ainz at this point. Another player or some op NPC hero at least teased but nope. We end the season like the last one was ended..... Ainz still uncontested and seems to be continuing to snow ball to world domination. At this point the introduction of another character to balance out Ainz will feel like its just being pulled out of the creators ass as therewill NEVER be enough build up to establish this antagonist to ainz unless the ENTIRE next season is spent building this supposed character up.\n\n
Would it be redeemable? hard to say, at this point I have lost any interest in any more seasons of this show and the lack of actual plot is really annoying. The issue is more with the source material being over rated and being built up with the hype when the plot is as deep as a puddle.

Welp we've finally reached the point in the show when having the main characters also be the Villains just isn't fun any more. It was kinda fun but eventually you simply can't root for the main character anymore. I mean it would be one thing if he had a good motive for doing the atrocities he does but it all comes down to well I guess if they think I should do it I might as well. Ainz also simply stops being cool this season he basically is repeatedly shown to be less intelligent then his underlings who are the ones who come up withall of his actually intelligent plans now, to the point were he's relegated to the role of fooling a bunch of people who worship the ground he stands on into thinking that he's smarter then he is, impressive. 


By the end I really just wanted the good guys to win but I knew that was never going to happen which just gave me this sense of hopelessness. What's worse it's not like the bad guys(main cast) are winning because their smart, don't get me wrong their smart and it definitly helps but their ultimately winning because their powers are all super freaking OP, to the point were other Isekai protagonists seem under powered. 


My question for this anime is, if these are the bad guys then were are the hero's to challenge them? Why should seeing them commit atrocities make me happy? If it's not meant to then why do you keep showing it? Were's their punishment? Am I supposed to root for them anyway? Aren't good villains meant too have strong motivations or at the very least, have motives?

I would give a 6/10 to the entire Overlord series, not just for Overlord III. Since I don't think an Overlord IV is coming out anytime soon, its safe to say that Overlord III is supposed to give the audience something exciting to watch while they wait for Overlord IV. On the contrary, Overlord III is about the same as the previous two seasons in the way that it introduces yet another set of characters as well as barely touching upon the plot. 
When I began to watch Overlord, I was expecting this villain character Ains to conquer the world. However, the first season didnot do this at all, he goes undercover to become Momonga the adventurer and that's basically it. So I thought "hey, maybe they will do it in the second season". Nope, We get introduced to some lizard people who don't matter later on and then we get introduced to a group of adventurers who also don't matter later on. To be fair, Ains does conquer the lizardmen, but it was no where near what I was expecting. So then I thought "maybe the third season will show him finally conquering things". Yea, I need to stop thinking things get better. (I'll put the problems I had about the story in the end because I think that's a spoiler and I like to put spoiler parts in the end.)


Something I had a problem with is the amount of dialogue this had. Whenever there was a major fight scene, fine, I can handle a little bit of trash talk where they say they will beat the other or something like that. But this made the fights drag on for far too long. It reminded me of Dragon ball where there's more dialogue than actual fighting. When the fighting did occur, the fight scenes weren't the best either. It was probably the dialogue every 10 seconds that really ruined it. But it was not action packed as other fights I've seen.


Another problem I had in general was the intro song. I usually don't care because I skip them anyway, but this song made me want to skip. In general I hate the sound of the music in the Overlord intro's.  I guess you can categorize this as electronic music, but I listen to electronic music and this sounds terrible, it sounds like a bunch of weird sounds put together.


Now onto the story. there will be spoilers.

**********SPOILERS AHEAD***********

So in the beginning we go back to the village Ains had saved in the first season. It focuses on how the girl leads the village and how Nphirea likes her and stuff. I don't see why it was necessary to go back again. I didn't really care about them. Again, I wanted to see Ains do things, not focus on some villagers. Then it is revealed that there are two other monsters of the forest and Ains goes and takes care of them. this is really the first part of the season. And I disliked this part because I really couldn't see how this would importantly affect the plot in any way. I'll tell you right now, even by the end of the season, I don't see why it focused on the village so much. 

Then we get introduced to some new adventurers that are hired to infiltrate a new ruin that was found. (It's Ain's decoy place I think). They go into it and then there are traps and stuff. I don't remember any of these people's names and they sure don't matter because they get killed off in like 3 episodes. So here's the thing: why introduce them in the first place? I think the writers wanted us to care about these characters because one of the adventurers has two sisters she wants to take care of on her own. But... three episodes is no where enough time to care about a character. It angers me because the adventurers could be cut out of the story entirely and nothing significant would change. They don't affect the plot. The infiltration of Ain's decoy base affected the plot because then Ains could talk to the empire who sent the tombraiders. They could easily have showed some people running into the base and then dying. They didn't need to introduce them and fill time.

Now the end of this season somewhat redeemed this to a score of 6 instead of a 4 or 5. Ains finally commands an army and he finally takes control of the city El-Rantel. I didn't think the army battle was anywhere as epic as it could have been because it just showed a bunch of cgi soldiers dying from giant black beasts. I didn't think the capture of the city was satisfying at all because the kingdom just gave it up to Ains. But honestly, after going through three seasons of this I'll take anything I can get. The sad thing is, the last two or three episodes of this advanced the plot further than the previous two seasons combined in my opinion. Seriously, You could watch the first episode of the first season and then the last episodes of this season and you wouldn't miss anything important.


******End of Spoiler*****


If you read all the way to here. First of all, thank you for reading this, it is my first review of something. It is nice to share what I feel about something.

TLDR: If you liked Overlord and Overlord II, read the Light Novel. This anime will only tarnish the series for you.
Overall	 6
Story	         10
Animation	 1
Sound	 7
Character	 7
Enjoyment	 4
Don't get me wrong, Overlord is a great story. I'd recommend the Light-Novel to anyone. Even the translated versions are great. After seeing the Anime on Crunchyroll, and watching the first season, I had to get more, so I read the Light-novel, and 1/2 way through book 5, Season II came out. I was so excited, and it was great! Even though the lizardmen arc was not the best part ofthe novel, the anime adaptation skipped over many of the more boring parts, and I actually thought the pacing was OK. I heard Season 3 was coming out this year and was super excited as well. "Another season!?" YES!!\n
Overlord III hit me with everything I didn't like from season two, plus obvious budget cuts destroyed the anime's art style to a point where halfway through the season it was more bad CGI than actual animation. I wish they had the budget to produce actual art, and hope that someone will make a fan recreation of the latter half of the season done right. The CGI, and the lack of care that went into making these episodes make it clear we will never get another season. They killed my favorite story.
